task_summary: Detect the T-block and the target zone, approach and align, establish contact, push the block in two segments toward the target, verify arrival, and retreat.

task_long_description.overview: A UR-style arm with a circular end-effector pushes a T-shaped block across a planar white workspace until it reaches a marked target zone. The behavior emphasizes reliable perception of the block and goal, careful approach and alignment to the block’s stem, establishing gentle contact, and executing a primary push followed by a short corrective push near the goal. Success is confirmed by a pose/region check, after which the robot retreats to a safe standoff. Observation and control are effectively discrete at 10 Hz.
preconditions: Workspace is clear except for the T-block and the marked target zone
Robot reachable workspace includes both start and goal regions
Camera view contains both block and target zone
stepwise_plan: Perceive the T-block and the target zone
Move above the T-block, align to its pushable face
Set tool yaw and perform a main push toward the goal
Re-align near the goal and perform a short corrective push
Verify the block is at the target zone and retreat
success_criteria: Block’s footprint overlaps the target zone
No collision with fixtures or table boundary
End-effector retreats to a safe distance
failure_and_recovery: Misalignment: re-approach and re-align before pushing
Insufficient displacement: execute short corrective push
task_long_description.termination: Tree succeeds when the block is detected at the target zone and the robot completes the retreat; it fails on unrecoverable perception or motion timeouts.

frame_3.now_evidence: End-effector aligned close to the block’s stem, suggesting imminent contact and push direction.

task_instruction: The task requires pushing a T-shaped block (gray) to a fixed target (green) with a circular end-effector (blue). Both observation and control frequencies are 10Hz.
recovery_strategy: Abort and retreat on repeated timeouts
assumptions: Colors in frames show a red block and blue outline target; instruction mentions gray block and green target—frames were prioritized.
IsAt(target_zone) is used as a proxy for the block’s presence at the goal via perception overlay.
Push direction_deg=0 chosen to match the apparent goal direction; actual scene frame provides this mapping.
10 Hz rates do not map to library ports; handled by controller outside the BT.

expected_success_criteria: Robot retreats without disturbing final pose
